creator: nathanc@tni.com
text:
Would it be necessary to decompress the gzipped file on the first iteration of
support?  JMeter does not currently try to "render" the HTML file before
reporting it's download speed.

However, I do see the importance of timing the decompression because the gzipped
file needs to be decompressed to be in the same "ready for rendering" state that
a non-gzipped file would be in.  This, of course, opens up the problem of which
files are actually gzipped and which are not, which is answered by the
Content-Encoding header field of the response.


Unless I am mistaken, in order to get the server to send you a gzipped file, all
you have to send as a header field is:

Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate

(e.g. conn.setRequestProperty("Accept-Encoding", "gzip, deflate") in the
setupConnection() method of the HTTPSampler.java file.)

JMeter shouldn't be asked to unzip because JMeter should not simulate client
processing - JMeter is one machine simulating many clients on a single CPU.  If
you have JMeter render HTML, unzip gzip files, execute javascript, etc, it would
only be meaningful if you stuck to a single thread.  Otherwise, it'll just bog
down the test machine and tell you nothing about how your server would perform
with 50 separate clients.
